title: Add locking in acquire-random-range-id
body:
This fixes a threadsafety issue documented in STORM-120. This is an
acceptable temporary fix, but the cause of concurrent access to this
variable should still be identified.

@revans2 suggested this fix.

Refs STORM-120

title: Add capability to remove keys from MemoryMapState
body: The implementation maintains proper opaque semantics, so if the batch is retried the keys will still be there. Keys are officially removed once the next batch starts. This also fixes a bug in OpaqueMap where get after put/update in the same batch wasn't working properly.

title: STORM-253: Allow storm worker to use dynamic port instead of pre-configed. Add a ne...
body:
PR for [STORM-253](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/STORM-253)

Allow supervisor to decide worker dynamiclly instead of pre-configured in configure file. This is especially useful in a shared cluster environment.

Changes:
1. Add a new config "supervisor.slots" to set the number of workers per supervisor.
2. Add class ServerSocketFactory to reserve the port for worker.

title: STORM-207: Add storm-starter under examples directory
body: This PR merges the storm-starter project into an `examples` directory (preserving commit history) and incorporates it into the maven build.

title: STORM-113: making thrift usage thread safe for local cluster
Add shade transformer for clojure code
body:
This fixes an issue caused by the maven-shade-plugin not relocating packages in clojure code.

It adds a `ResourceTransformer` so that when the maven shade plugin relocates packages java bytecode (in our case `org.apache.thrift` --> `org.apache.thrift7`), it will also perform the package transformations for clojure code in the shaded jar.

I need to do more testing across different platforms before merging this, but it should fix the issue that forced the cancellation of the last release, but so far it works well in a distributed multi-node cluster.

title: Added logging level to multilang protocol spout and bolt.
Added logging level to multilang protocol spout and bolt.
Move shading of the thrift dependency to storm-core
body:
(Addresses STORM-198, and provides potential future path for STORM-129 (AKA #115 -- "Dependency Isolation")

The way we were repackaging the thrift jar before caused maven build problems for a lot of people. We were trying to create a shaded jar (package renaming) in a submodule, then use it as a dependency in other modules. The maven-shade-plugin only allows you to to the `package` or later phases.  So trying to run `mvn test` from the root directory would fail because the shaded dependency would not have been created, resulting in compilation errors.

It also wreaked havoc with the maven-release-plugin, making it virtually impossible to release.

This pull requests eliminates that problem by moving the thrift repackaging to the storm-core module.

With this approach, the java imports in source code use the package names as they were before shading, and the package renaming happens when the jar file is built. 

This makes it dead easy to isolate dependencies so they don't conflict with user dependencies. For example, a few lines in the storm-core pom could repackage the Guava dependency (which I would actually suggest we do since Guava seems to be the poster child for this type of issue).

title: Submit jvmopts as array of argument values
body:
jvmopts was being supplied as an array of a single string element. Executing the following command to submit a topology would not supply the `STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS` value appropriately:

`STORM_JAR_JVM_OPTS="-Dhurricane.env=production" storm jar target/scala-2.9.2/hurricane-assembly-0.1.jar topologies.HeavenTopology`

I modeled jvmopts off of other examples in the same script.

title: Switch from Leiningen to Maven
body:
This is a work-in-progress, but I'd appreciate any feedback.
### Summary

This patch changes the build system from Leiningen to Maven, which will greatly simplify the Apache release process. I've tried to retain the Leiningen/Clojure-friendly features of the previous build system as much as possible. Any IDE with Maven support should be able to import the project (I've tested with Intellij IDEA).
#### Maven Modules

This is a multi-module build, consisting of the following modules:
- **storm-deps** -- This is a collection of storm dependencies that need to be shaded/repackaged (i.e. java package names changed to avoid dependency conflicts). Currently only the `libthrift` dependency is shaded/repackaged, but additional packaged could be added in the future.
- **storm-core** -- This module contains the majority of the storm code (clojure, java, python, etc.). This could be broken down into further submodules, but that isn't necessary yet.
- **storm-dist** -- This module creates project distribution/release artifacts (both source and binary) with the necessary signatures. 
#### Developers

All the Storm code (for now) resides in `storm-core`. 
##### Initial Settup

If you are building from a fresh checkout, you will need to either run a top-level install (`mvm install`) from the source root directory, or run `mvm install` in the `storm-deps\libthrift` directory. The `storm-deps` submodule contains modules that repackage Storm dependencies (by changing the package name) in order to avoid runtime conflicts with users' topology dependencies. 

Currently only the Apache Thift dependency is shaded.
###### REPL support

You can run a Leiningen-style REPL by running the following command in `storm-core`:

```
$ mvn clojure:repl
```
#### Committers/Release Managers

The following command will build everything, generate documentation and reports, sign artifacts, and deploy (for now we only deploy to `/tmp`):

```
mvn clean install site site:deploy -P dist,sign
```

Reports can then be found in `/tmp/site/index.htm`.

Key reports include:
- Apache RAT (Release Audit Tool): `/tmp/site/rat-report.html`
- Project Dependencies: `/tmp/site/dependencies.html`

We have not upmerged to the latest apache code yet, so this may not be perfect, especially with the versions of dependencies.  Also the clojure plugins should probably move to the latest versions.

body: Testing.

title: Replace 0MQ with Netty
body:
This is required in order to release from Apache. Because 0MQ/JZMQ is LGPL-licensed, it can't be included as a dependency in Apache releases.

This patch simply removes JZMQ/0MQ and replaces it with the netty transport implementation.

We can still make the 0MQ transport available to users who want to use it. But it will have to be a separate project that's not part of Apache. I will follow up with creating a repo that has the 0MQ transport code in isolation.

title: Remove `unzip` dependency
body:
Rather than call out to an external `unzip` command to extract resources, this change uses pure clojure java interop to do so, eliminating the need for the `unzip` dependency.

With this and the Netty transport in place, Storm would no longer have any native dependencies. This will make installing storm easier, particularly on Windows where finding an `unzip.exe` that's compatible with the unix `unzip` command can be a challenge.

title: Use Stock libthrift dependency
body:
This is hopefully a temporary workaround for the fact that storm has been using a non-stock build of the libthrift dependency. Hopefully it will spur discussions that lead to a better solution.

It works by downloading the stock libthrift jar, uses jarjar to rewrite package names, then installs the resulting jar in the local maven repository where leiningen and maven will be able to find it.

One downside is that users would have to run ./bin/install_libthrift.sh (only once) before building from source. So it kind of muddies the build process.

Ideally I'd like to see this functionality integrated with the leiningen build process so we don't rely on one-off shell scripts to build.

title: Storm windows support (resubmit)
body: This is a resubmission of @davidlao2k's https://github.com/nathanmarz/storm/pull/722 that got merged into the wrong branch and never made it into the 0.9.0 releases.

title: Removed duplicate key: :javac-options
body:
Building storm causes errors due to a duplicate `:javac-options`
entries in the `storm-core/project.clj`.

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Duplicate key:
:javac-options
```

I have merged the `:javac-options` into a single entry.

title: Prevent Nimbus from hanging if random data is sent to nimbus thrift port
body:
Currently if random data is sent to Nimbus' thrift port, it will result in the following error, causing Nimbus to hang:

`java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space`

Situations where this can happen:
- Inadvertently ssh'ing to the nimbus port (`ssh nimbus -p 6627`)
- Telnetting to the nimbus port (`telnet nimbus 6627`)
- Network security/vulnerability scans that probe port 6627

The solution is to set a limit on the size of the buffers Thrift uses for reading messages. With this fix in place when any of the above occurs, the following will appear in the nimbus log (but nimbus will not hang or crash):

```
2013-12-13 17:10:52 o.a.t.s.TNonblockingServer [ERROR] Read a frame size of 1397966893, which is bigger than the maximum allowable buffer size for ALL connections.
```
